help.guidance: When identifying images and photos, look for realistic representations of objects, people, or scenes.
Diagrams typically use simplified shapes, lines, and labels to represent concepts or structures.
Workflows and architectures often use boxes, arrows, or other connectors to show relationships and processes.
Figures may include various types of charts, graphs, or plots, often with axes and data points.
Pay attention to captions and in-text references, as they often provide context and identify the type of visual element.
Consider the purpose of the visual element in relation to the surrounding text - is it illustrative, explanatory, or presenting data?
Note any color coding or legends used to convey additional information within the visual element.
For complex visuals, break down the analysis into components (e.g., main elements, labels, color scheme).
If you encounter a visual element that doesn't fit the predefined categories, describe its key features and purpose as best you can.
Remember that some visual elements may combine multiple types (e.g., a diagram within a photograph) - be prepared to describe these hybrid forms.
